content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <rdf:RDF  xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"  xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  xmlns:prism="http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/">   <channel rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar">     <title>The Unfamiliar</title>   <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar</link>            <description><p>The Unfamiliar is a postgraduate student-led journal based at the University of Edinburgh, aimed at making anthropology easily and widely accessible to audiences beyond academia. We seek to provide a forum for postgraduate students and early-career researchers for the publication of, and creative engagement with, their research.\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>           <dc:publisher>University of Edinburgh</dc:publisher>         <dc:language>en-US</dc:language>      <prism:publicationName>The Unfamiliar</prism:publicationName>               <prism:issn>2050-778X</prism:issn>         <prism:copyright><p>Authors who publish with this journal agree to the following terms:</p><p>a. Authors retain copyright and grant the journal right of first publication with the work simultaneously licensed under an Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 2.5 UK: Scotland license\ufffd\ufffd that allows others to share the work with an acknowledgement of the work's authorship and initial publication in this journal.</p><p>More information on Creative Commons here: <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/scotland/">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/scotland/</a></p><p>b. Authors are able to enter into separate, additional contractual arrangements for the non-exclusive distribution of the journal's published version of the work (e.g., post it to an institutional repository or publish it in a book), with an acknowledgement of its initial publication in this journal.</p><p>c. Authors are permitted and encouraged to post their work online (e.g., in institutional repositories or on their website) prior to and during the submission process, as it can lead to productive exchanges, as well as earlier and greater citation of published work (See <a href="http://opcit.eprints.org/oacitation-biblio.html" target="_new">The Effect of Open Access</a>).</p></prism:copyright> rdf:resource="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1095"/>                 <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1061"/>           </rdf:Seq>   </items>  </channel>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1132">        <title>A Letter from the Editors: Imagining the Future</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1132</link>                <dc:creator>Hakon Caspersen</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Inna Yaneva-Toraman</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1113">        <title>Between Heaven and a Hard Place: Inhabiting the Space Between an Enchanted Past and a Utopian Future</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1113</link>            <description><p>This essay looks at how devotees of Krishna in Mayapur, West Bengal experience the space between an ideal past and a prophesied future. Through an affective and imaginative engagement with Vaishnav cultural history, devotees learn to relocate themselves in a particular temporal flow, within which both the past and future become constitutive horizons of the ethical imagination. I will focus on how the tradition of katha (storytelling) facilitates a convergence of temporalities, within which devotees are encouraged to routinely participate in the past. Such engagement with an enchanted past, I will argue, in turn informs devotees\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd imaginings of and aspirations for the ongoing development of an \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIdeal Vedic City\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.</p></description>            <dc:creator>John Fahy</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1097">        <title>Designing an Illusion of India\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Future Superpowerdom</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1097</link>            <description><p>The article dissects current utopian visions of future Indian superpowerdom and traces them to underlying convergences between right wing political Hindu nationalism and philanthrocapitalism. By looking at how utopian visions are materialized in the elitist aesthetics of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdroyal chic\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd parading on New Delhi\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds fashion ramps and in the aesthetics of hypermodern smart cities of the future, the article explores the aesthetic and affective convergence of an imagined economy and (re-)invented traditions. In the problematic terrain of philanthrocapitalism, the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfactish\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of GDP and the <em>doxa</em> of Indianness have come to form the core of current populist myths. In so doing they produce an illusion of future India that nobody really believes in, yet structures reality and is passionately embraced by many. The article suggests that the problem with such utopian myths is not that they are myths, but rather it is the direction they are pushing in and their consequences which require questioning. The article provides preliminary analysis of, and answers around, this problematic of resonant versus dissonant futures and their imaginaries.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Tereza Kuldova</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1109">        <title>Building Castles in the Air</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1109</link>            <description>.</description>            <dc:creator>Ian M. Cook</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1112">        <title>Tomorrow, might there be glory</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1112</link>                <dc:creator>Sebastien Bachelet</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Houdou undisclosed</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1103">        <title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdI was at Home!\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd The Dream of Representation in the Representation of a Dream.</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1103</link>            <description>This creative essay uses a dream the author had during fieldwork as the starting point for a discussion of the conundrums of representation. The dream epitomises the alterations that observation causes on the portions of reality that the ethnographer selects and concentrates upon. The rest of the essay tells of how the author attempted to find his own personal solution to the problem of representation thanks to inspiration found in a photo exhibition and the letter of a friend and mentor. Such interpenetration of oneiric, photographic, and epistolary materials works as a pretext to discuss the importance of remaining faithful to the anthropological mission of making people visible and not being hindered by the methodological impossibility of representation.</description>            <dc:creator>Rodolfo Maggio</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>    <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1088">        <title>an etymology of desire: de sidere, from the stars</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1088</link>            <description>This poem attempts to explore the dynamics between time, desire, and our capacity to dream, and how that in turn impacts our perceptions of ourselves.</description>            <dc:creator>Emily Lynn Cook</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1095">        <title>Stillness as a Form of Imaginative Labour</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1095</link>            <description><p>This essay connects the practice of stillness to David Graeber's concepts of imaginative labour and immanent imagination. It makes the proposition that stillness should not be evaluated as lack of activity or movement, but rather attended to in its pragmatic and productive dimensions. The essay thus explores stillness as a potential mode of production of imagination and means of political transformation: in order for it to be meaningful, we need to reconfigure our relationship to stillness as one of imagination, resistance, thinking, and writing.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Theodoros Kyriakides</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-22</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-22</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1061">        <title>The Story of the End of the World: An Alternative Approach to the Future at the Japanese Museum of Science and Innovation</title>    <link>http://journals.ed.ac.uk/unfamiliar/article/view/1061</link>            <description><p>The following discussion is a critical assessment of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdStory of the End of the World: 73 Questions We Must Answer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, an exhibition at the Miraikan. The Tohoku earthquake and tsunami on the 11<sup>th</sup> of March 2011 created the necessity for collective catharsis regarding various threats posed by the future. I will argue that the outcome of the exhibition differs significantly in content, presentation and meaning to the more conventional <strong>visions of the future</strong> presented elsewhere in the museum.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Michael Shea</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-02</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-02</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>4</prism:volume>   </item>  </rdf:RDF>
